140 civilians (mostly children) killed in [[2014 Peshawar school attack|TTP retaliation]] | campaignbox = {{Campaignbox Waziristan}} }}'''Operation Zarb-e-Azb''' ([[Pashto]]/{{lang-ur|آپریشن ضربِ عضب}} [[ALA-LC]]: {{transl|ur|ALA-LC|''Āpres̱ẖan Ẓarb-i ʿAẓb''}} {{IPA-ur|ɑːpreːʃən zərb-e əzb|pron}}) was a [[Joint Chiefs of Staff Committee|joint military]] [[Offensive (military)|offensive]] conducted by the [[Pakistan Armed Forces]] against various [[Militant (word)|militant]] groups, including the [[Tehrik-i-Taliban Pakistan]] (TTP), the [[Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan]], the [[East Turkestan Islamic Movement]], [[Lashkar-e-Jhangvi]], [[al-Qaeda]], [[Jundallah (Pakistan)|Jundallah]] and the [[Haqqani network]]. The operation was launched on 15 June 2014 in [[North Waziristan]] along the [[Durand Line|Pakistan-Afghanistan border]] as a renewed effort against militancy in the wake of the [[2014 Jinnah International Airport attack|8 June attack on Jinnah International Airport]] in Karachi, for which the TTP and the IMU claimed responsibility.{{cite news|last1=Khan|first1=Wajahat S|title=Zarb-e-Azb: Gear up for the 'forever war'|url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/Todays-News-13-33451-Zarb-e-Azb-Gear-up-for-the-forever-war|accessdate=10 January 2015|work=A series of special reports on Operation Zarb-e-Azb by the newspaper's National Security Editor.|agency=News International|publisher=News International, 2014 editorial|date=14 October 2014}}{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/1112909/zarb-e-azb-operation-120-suspected-militants-killed-in-n-waziristan|title=Zarb-e-Azb operation: 120 suspected militants killed in N Waziristan|newspaper=[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]]|date=15 June 2014|accessdate=16 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6R2YSytX0 |archivedate=13 July 2014}} As of 14 July 2014, the operation [[Internally displaced person|internally displaced]] about 929,859 people belonging to 80,302 families from North Waziristan. Part of the [[war in North-West Pakistan]], up to 30,000 Pakistani soldiers were involved in Zarb-e-Azb, described as a "comprehensive operation" to flush out all foreign and local militants hiding in North Waziristan.{{cite news|agency=Associated Press|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/06/15/pakistan-army-says-launch_n_5496487.html|title=Pakistan Launches Offensive Against Militants Near Afghan Border|work=[[Huffington Post]]|accessdate=23 June 2014|date=15 June 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QhxuqpnN|archivedate=30 June 2014}} The operation has received widespread support from the Pakistani political, defence and civilian sectors. As a consequence, the overall security situation improved and terrorist attacks in Pakistan dropped to a six-year low since 2008.{{cite news|title=Militant attacks declined after Zarb-e-Azb operation: report|url=http://nation.com.pk/national/17-Jun-2015/militant-attacks-declined-after-zarb-e-azb-operation-report|date=17 June 2015 |work=The Nation|accessdate=17 June 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ZMTJiLoJ|archivedate=17 June 2015}} Zarb-e-Azb was followed by [[Operation Radd-ul-Fasaad]] which began in February 2017, following a resurgence in terrorist incidents. ==Etymologies== ''Zarb-e-Azb'' ({{lang-ur|{{nq|ضربِ عضب}}}} [[ALA-LC]]: {{transl|ur|ALA-LC|''Ẓarb-i ʿAẓb''}} {{IPA-ur|zərb-e əzb|pron}}) means "sharp and cutting strike".{{cite news|last=Desk |first=Web |url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/722202/army-launches-operation-in-north-waziristan/ |title=Operation Zarb-e-Azb updates |work=The Express Tribune |date=10 June 2014 |accessdate=15 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6R2YUi35i |archivedate=13 July 2014}} ''Azb'' also refers to the sword owned by the Islamic prophet [[Muhammad]], which he used in the battles of [[Battle of Badr|Badr]] and [[Battle of Uhud|Uhud]].{{cite news|url=http://dunyanews.tv/index.php/en/Pakistan/225567-Negotiations-end-Pak-Army-formally-launches-opera |title=Negotiations end, Pak Army formally launches operation Zarb-e-Azb against terrorists; Dunya News |publisher=Dunyanews.tv |accessdate=15 June 2014 | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qhy6yCMS | archivedate=30 June 2014}} ==Strategy== For the first time, the Pakistani military implemented a military strategy called "Seek, Destroy, Clear, Hold." The Pakistani military will seek the target. Once found, it will be destroyed. When destroyed, the infrastructure, bodies and weapons will be cleared and the area will be held both during this time and after its completion to ensure post-operation security and infrastructure rebuilding and/or area rehabilitation. The [[Seek and Destroy]] component is from the [[Vietnam War]] whereas the [[Clear and hold]] component is from the [[Iraq War]]. The Pakistani military combined the two doctrines as a single doctrine for the operation to be successful. ==Background== ==={{anchor|Peace-negotiations}}Peace negotiations=== Peace negotiations with the [[Taliban]] were announced by Pakistani Prime Minister [[Nawaz Sharif]] after his election,{{cite news|author=Shahzeb Jillani |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-26065385 |title=Pakistan enters peace talks with Taliban |publisher=BBC |date=6 February 2014 |accessdate=15 June 2014 | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qhy9iNEJ | archivedate=30 June 2014}} although previous attempts to engage TTP in dialogue had failed. The first session of talks, between committees appointed by the [[Government of Pakistan|Pakistani Government]] and the Taliban, was held on 26 March 2014 at Khyber Pakhtunkhwa House in [[Islamabad]].{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-26731838 |title=First day of Pakistan Taliban peace talks concluded |publisher=BBC |date=26 March 2014 |accessdate=15 June 2014 | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QhyCYa5e | archivedate=30 June 2014}} The Taliban did not name representatives from their ranks, instead nominating pro-Taliban religious figures to present their views. The terrorists called for the implementation of [[Sharia]] in Pakistan; the Government of Pakistan demanded the cessation of hostilities, insisting that talks be held within the framework of the [[Constitution of Pakistan|Pakistani constitution]]. A month-long ceasefire was reached on 1 March 2014.{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/1090330/pakistani-taliban-announce-month-long-ceasefire |title=Pakistani Taliban announce month-long ceasefire – Pakistan |work=Dawn|location=Pakistan |accessdate=15 June 2014 | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QhyFIeIf | archivedate=30 June 2014}} Besides the meetings at Khyber Pakhtunkhwa House, negotiations also involved helicopter travel by government representatives to the areas under militant control near the Pakistan-Afghanistan border. The government had indicated that stronger military action would be implemented if the talks failed. ===={{anchor|Peace-negotiations failure}}Failure==== Negotiations collapsed after the execution of 23 Pakistani [[Frontier Corps]] soldiers by the Taliban on 17 February 2014.{{cite news|last=Crilly |first=Rob |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/pakistan/10643505/Peace-talks-collapse-as-Taliban-execute-23-Pakistani-soldiers.html |title=Peace talks collapse as Taliban execute 23 Pakistani soldiers |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=17 February 2014 |accessdate=15 June 2014 | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QhyPnMw2 | archivedate=30 June 2014}}{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/02/17/us-pakistan-taliban-idUSBREA1G0MP20140217 | title=Peace talks between Pakistan and Taliban collapse after killings | work=Maria Golovnina and Amjad Ali | date=17 February 2014 | agency=Reuters | accessdate=15 June 2014 | last=Golovnina | first=Maria | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QhyTWnhp | archivedate=30 June 2014}} The soldiers had been held by the insurgents since 2010, and on 17 April 2014 the TTP formally ended the ceasefire.{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/1100415/ttp-ends-ceasefire-says-talks-option-open |title=TTP ends ceasefire, says talks option open – Newspaper |work=Dawn|location=Pakistan |date=17 April 2014 |accessdate=15 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6R2Yjslgm |archivedate=13 July 2014}} Taliban infighting since March 2014 killed more than 90 militants. The strife, triggered by differences between the Mehsud group (led by Sheheryar Mehsud) and another TTP faction (led by Khan Said Sajna), impeded the negotiations.{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/1107309 |title=Taliban infighting impedes Pakistan peace talks – Pakistan |work=Dawn|location=Pakistan |accessdate=15 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6R2Yizs1P |archivedate=13 July 2014}} The negotiations were irreversibly damaged by a terrorist attack on Karachi Airport for which the Taliban claimed responsibility and which killed 28 people (including security personnel).{{cite news|author=Jon Boone in Islamabad |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jun/09/pakistan-taliban-karachi-attack-peace-talks |title=Pakistani Taliban claim Karachi attack and leave peace talks in crisis |work=The Guardian |accessdate=15 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6R2Ycr2d0 |archivedate=13 July 2014}} A Pakistani military official was quoted to have said, "The army is ready for an operation."{{cite news |url=https://online.wsj.com/articles/gunmen-attack-karachi-airport-1402301470 |title=Pakistan Weighs Strike Against Taliban Over Airport Attack | work=The Wall Street Journal | date=9 June 2014 | last=Shah | first=Saeed|subscription=yes}} ===Jinnah Airport attack=== {{main|2014 Jinnah International Airport attack}} The operation began one week after a terrorist attack on Pakistan's busiest airport. On 8 June 2014, 10 militants from the [[Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan]] and TTP attacked [[Jinnah International Airport]], [[Karachi]], killing 28 people including security personnel and wounding at least 18.{{cite news|title=Heavy fighting reported at Karachi airport|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/asia/2014/06/heavy-fighting-reported-at-karachi-airport-201468185852200231.html|publisher=[[Al Jazeera]]|accessdate=8 June 2014|date=8 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6R2Yfj13O |archivedate=13 July 2014}} In retaliation, the Pakistani military launched a series of air-strikes targeting terrorist hideouts in the areas bordering Afghanistan. At least 25 militants were killed on 10 June. The figure also included foreign militants killed.{{cite news|last=Desk |first=Web |url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/719855/aerial-bombing-in-tirah-valley-kills-15-militants/ |title=Aerial bombing in Tirah valley kills 25 militants |work=The Express Tribune |accessdate=17 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6R8SJt8xK |archivedate=17 July 2014}} Two [[Drone attacks in Pakistan|drone attacks]] on 12 June killed Uzbek, Afghan and local militants.{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/1112050 |title=Successive drone strikes leave at least 16 dead in N Waziristan – Pakistan |work=Dawn|location=Pakistan |accessdate=17 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6R8SEhJad |archivedate=17 July 2014}}{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/1112253 |title=Drone targeted Haqqani network commander, Afghan Taliban: sources – Pakistan |work=Dawn|location=Pakistan |accessdate=17 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6R8SEsghG |archivedate=17 July 2014}} On 15 June the Pakistani military intensified air-strikes and bombed eight foreign militant hideouts, killing as many as 140 militants (most Uzbek, including persons linked to the airport attack and airport attack commander and mastermind Abu Abdur Rehman Almani) in [[North Waziristan]].{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/1112875/mostly-uzbeks-killed-in-overnight-n-waziristan-bombing-army |title=Mostly Uzbeks killed in overnight N Waziristan bombing: army – Pakistan |work=Dawn|location=Pakistan |accessdate=15 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6R8SF2Fkc |archivedate=17 July 2014}}{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/1112901/ |title=Karachi airport attack mastermind killed in N Waziristan: Sources – Pakistan |work=Dawn|location=Pakistan |accessdate=15 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6R8SF81Vs |archivedate=17 July 2014}} ==Preparations== {{quote box |quote = Using North Waziristan as a base, these terrorists had waged a war against the state of Pakistan and had been disrupting our national life in all its dimensions, stunting our economic growth and causing enormous loss of life and property. They had also paralyzed life within the agency and had perpetually terrorized the entire peace loving and patriotic local population.|Inter-Services Public Relations{{citation|url=https://www.ispr.gov.pk/front/main.asp?o=t-press_release&date=2014/6/15|title=Press Releases of 15 June|date=15 June 2014|accessdate=20 June 2014|publisher=[[Inter-Services Public Relations|ISPR]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QTf3gYKo|archivedate=20 June 2014}}{{cite news|author=Omer Farooq Khan |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/pakistan/Pak-military-launches-onslaught-against-Taliban/articleshow/36616779.cms |title=Pak military launches onslaught against Taliban |work=The Times of India |accessdate=16 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6R8SX3rB7 |archivedate=17 July 2014}}|}} The [[Pakistani military]] had prepared for the operation long before, and the government prepared for a three-front operation:{{cite news|author=آصف فاروقی بی بی سی اردو ڈاٹ کام، اسلام آباد |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/urdu/pakistan/2014/06/140615_preperation_waziristan_operation_tim.shtml |title=پاکستان – BBC Urdu – 'حکومت نے آپریشن کے لیے 3 محاذوں پر تیاری کی' |publisher=BBC |date=1 January 1970 |accessdate=16 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6R8SX5gtp |archivedate=17 July 2014}} isolating targeted militant groups, obtaining support from the political parties and saving civilians from the backlash of the operation. [[Defence Minister of Pakistan|Defence Minister]] [[Khawaja Muhammad Asif|Khawaja Asif]] said that the nation stood by its military: "The decision was taken after the strategy of dialogue failed. The operation will continue until it reaches its logical conclusion. Any group that challenges Pakistan's constitution, attacks civilians, soldiers, and government installations and uses Pakistani territory to plan terrorist attacks will be targeted". Asif added that [[internally displaced person]]s would be assisted by the federal and [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa]] governments: "We will try to ensure that the displaced do not have to stay away from their homes for too long."{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/1112910/supporters-and-critics-weigh-in-on-operation |title=Supporters and critics weigh in on operation – Pakistan |work=Dawn|location=Pakistan |accessdate=15 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6R8SXCCpR |archivedate=17 July 2014}} ''' The combat troops encircled militant bases in the towns of Mirali and [[Miranshah]]. Pakistani officials said that the Afghan's [[Afghan National Security Forces|National Security Forces]] (ANSF) were requested to seal the border on their side so that militants do not escape.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-27858234 |title=Pakistan army launches 'major offensive' in North Waziristan |publisher=BBC |date=15 June 2014 |accessdate=16 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6R8SXFwSP |archivedate=17 July 2014}} The operation involved the [[Pakistan Air Force|Air Force]], [[Pakistan Navy|Navy]] [[artillery]], [[tank]]s and [[Infantry|ground troop]]s. According to a military statement, "On the directions of the government, armed forces of Pakistan have launched a comprehensive operation against foreign and local terrorists who are hiding in sanctuaries in North Waziristan." An official with the military said that between 14,000 and 20,000 soldiers were normally stationed in North Waziristan before the operation, and he expected the offensive to require no more than a Agency]] ====June==== {{term|15 June 2014}} {{defn|The first phase of the operation began with intensified airstrikes in [[North Waziristan]], targeting militant training facilities, hideouts, and other infrastructure.{{cite news |url=http://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2014/06/26/national/operation-zarb-e-azb-ground-offensive-initiates/ | title=Operation Zarb-e-Azb: Ground offensive initiates | work=Pakistan Today | date=26 June 2014 | accessdate=27 June 2014 | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QeMPrEEF | archivedate=27 June 2014}} The Pakistani military destroyed eight militant hideouts in the previous night's airstrikes. Hideouts in Degan-Boya and Datta Khel were targeted by jet aircraft, since foreign and local insurgents linked to the Karachi airport attack were confirmed there; an [[ammunition dump]] was also destroyed. As many as 140 militants (mostly Uzbek) were reportedly killed in the strikes, including commander and airport attack mastermind Abu Abdur Rehman Almani.{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/1112901/ |title=Karachi airport attack mastermind killed in N Waziristan: Sources – Pakistan |work=Dawn|location=Pakistan |accessdate=15 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6R8SF81Vs |archivedate=17 July 2014}}{{Citation |url=https://www.ispr.gov.pk/front/main.asp?o=t-press_release&date=2014/6/16 | title=Press Releases of 16 June | date=16 June 2014 | publisher=[[Inter-Services Public Relations|ISPR]] | accessdate=20 June 2014 | archivedate=20 June 2014 | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QOLL3dUF}} North Waziristan was sealed by troops on its border with neighbouring [[Federally Administered Tribal Areas#Administrative divisions|agencies]] and [[Federally Administered Tribal Areas#Frontier Regions|FATA regions]] to block the movement of militants. In North Waziristan, troops cordoned off insurgent bases (including those in the towns of Mir Ali and Miranshah). Logistical and administrative arrangements for IDPs were made by the Disaster Management Agency, with the establishment of registration points and IDP camps. Surrender points were established for militants wishing to give up their arms. Aerial surveillance of the area was conducted. Afghan security forces were requested to seal the border on their side to prevent militants from escaping across the border and initiate immediate measures to eliminate TTP militants and their hideouts in Kunar, Nuristan and elsewhere in Afghanistan.}} {{term|16 June 2014}} {{defn|Seven fleeing militants were killed on the outskirts of Mirali overnight, with three soldiers injured in the exchange of fire. In a separate incident, seven more militants were killed when they tried to flee from the cordoned-off area. Two Pakistani soldiers were reported killed in an exchange of gunfire. Six militant hideouts in Shawal, North Waziristan were destroyed by an early-morning airstrike by two fighter jets, with 27 militants killed. There were no civilians in Shawal.{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/1113108 |title=NWA operation: Seven more militants killed; toll rises to 187 – Pakistan |work=Dawn|location=Pakistan |accessdate=16 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QNXJnCLm |archivedate=16 June 2014}}{{cite news|url=http://dunyanews.tv/index.php/en/Pakistan/225598-North-Waziristan-12-militants-killed-in-air-strik |title=North Waziristan: 12 militants killed in air strikes |publisher=Dunyanews.tv |accessdate=16 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6R8SXR7dL |archivedate=17 July 2014}} [[Inter-Services Public Relations]] (ISPR) reported six soldiers killed and three injured in an [[improvised explosive device]] (IED) explosion between the Afghan border and Ghulam Khan Tehsil in North Waziristan. According to ISPR, a convoy of security forces was targeted on Bane Dar Road in [[Ghulam Khan]] (on the Pakistani-Afghan border). Forces cordoned off the area, launching a search operation. Three insurgents were killed by [[Special Services Group]] sniper fire while planting IEDs near Miramshah.}} {{term|17 June 2014}} {{defn|Airstrikes destroyed six hideouts in North Waziristan, killing 25 foreign and local militants. Airstrikes were also conducted in the Hasokhel area of [[Mir Ali, Pakistan|Mir Ali]].{{citation|url=https://www.ispr.gov.pk/front/main.asp?o=t-press_release&date=2014/6/17|title=Press Release No PR131/2014-ISPR|publisher=[[Inter-Services Public Relations|ISPR]]|date=17 June 2014|accessdate=17 June 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QP2aqcVW|archivedate=17 June 2014}} At least three suspected militants were killed when they attempted to flee a cordoned-off area in Miramshah, with one soldier injured in the exchange of fire.{{cite news |url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/723501/fresh-blitz-kills-28-more-militants/ | title=Fresh blitz kills 28 more militants | work=The Express Tribune | date=18 June 2014 | accessdate=18 June 2014 | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QSAnKVwp | archivedate=18 June 2014 }} No operations had begun in developed areas to ensure that no militants could escape the cordon and all verified civilians were evacuated. More than 40 percent of North Waziristan was cleared of militants in the first three days of the operation.{{cite news |url=http://www.express.pk/story/263750/ | title=دہشت گردوں سے شمالی وزیرستان کے40 فیصد سے زائد علاقے کو خالی کرالیا گیا | work=Amir Khan | date=18 June 2014 | agency=Express News | accessdate=18 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6R8SXXc4S |archivedate=17 July 2014}}}} {{term|19 June 2014}} {{defn|Fifteen militants were reportedly killed overnight in the Zartatangi Heights, east of Miramshah, by army [[Bell AH-1 Cobra#Pakistan|Cobra helicopter gunships]]. The area was one of the main communications centres of the insurgents.{{citation|url=https://www.ispr.gov.pk/front/main.asp?o=t-press_release&date=2014/6/19|title=Press Release No PR135/2014-ISPR|date=19 June 2014|accessdate=19 June 2014|publisher=[[Inter-Services Public Relations|ISPR]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QSzoSmMv|archivedate=20 June 2014}} In a separate incident, eight Uzbek militants were killed near Miramshah while planting IEDs on the road between Miramshah and Mir Ali. The evacuation of the civilian population from Miramshah and Ghulam Khan began. Checkpoints were established in a number of locations, where IDPs received food and medicine from security forces. As many as 400 Afghan families left North Waziristan for Afghanistan via Ghulam Khan.{{Citation |url=https://www.ispr.gov.pk/front/main.asp?o=t-press_release&date=2014/6/20 | title=Press Releases of 20 June | date=20 June 2014 | publisher=[[Inter-Services Public Relations|ISPR]] | accessdate=20 June 2014 | archivedate=20 June 2014 | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QTf3bfrQ}}}} {{term|20 June 2014}} {{defn|Three militant hideouts in the Qutab Khel area, on the outskirts of Miramshah, were destroyed in the early morning by army Cobra helicopter gunships with artillery and sniper assistance. Twelve militants, including some foreigners, were killed in the strikes and a large cache of arms and ammunition destroyed. Militants inside cordoned-off areas attempted to flee. Six attempts were halted overnight, and three local residents without identification were arrested trying to flee from the cordon. Another 24 suspects disguised as IDPs were arrested at [[security checkpoint]]s in Mirali and Miramshah. The civilian evacuation continued from North Waziristan towards [[Bannu]], with 200,000 IDPs evacuated so far.}} {{term|21 June 2014}} {{defn|A total of 30 militants were killed in early-morning airstrikes in uninhabited areas of Khyber and North Waziristan Agencies. Jet aircraft destroyed two hideouts near the Pakistan-Afghanistan border in Khyber Agency, killing 10 militants. These surgical strikes were in line with the security forces' strategy to take on the militants across the FATA.{{citation|url=https://www.ispr.gov.pk/front/main.asp?o=t-press_release&date=2014/6/21|title=Press Releases of 21 June|date=21 June 2014|accessdate=21 June 2014|publisher=[[Inter-Services Public Relations|ISPR]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QV2B9MOD|archivedate=21 June 2014}}{{cite news |url=http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/national/22-Jun-2014/30-more-terrorists-killed-in-nwa-khyber-agency-strikes | title=30 more terrorists killed in NWA, Khyber Agency strikes | work=Daily Times | date=22 June 2014 | accessdate=24 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6R8Sklgyr |archivedate=17 July 2014}} Three hideouts were destroyed in Hassu Khel, North Waziristan, killing 20 militants.}} {{term|23 June 2014}} {{defn|Eight militant hideouts near Mir Ali were destroyed by jet aircraft during the early morning, killing 15. Tunnels were spotted in the targeted areas.{{Citation |url=https://www.ispr.gov.pk/front/main.asp?o=t-press_release&date=2014/6/23 | title=Press Releases of 23 June | date=23 June 2014 | publisher=[[Inter-Services Public Relations|ISPR]] | accessdate=23 June 2014 | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QZgni4V4 | archivedate=24 June 2014}} Ten militants were killed attempting to flee from cordoned-off bases in Spinwam and Mir Ali, with two Pakistani soldiers also reportedly killed in an exchange of fire. The curfew was lifted for two hours to evacuate the remaining civilians. At the Saidgai security checkpoint, 414,429 IDPs were registered to date. An army medical corps field hospital was being established in Bannu for displaced persons. The civilian evacuation was almost complete. About 450,000 IDPs arrived in Bannu, and were registered at the Saidgai checkpoint.{{cite news |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2014-06/24/c_133431283.htm | title=Over 450,000 people displaced in northwestern Pakistan | agency=Xinhua News Agency | date=23 June 2014 | accessdate=24 June 2014 | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QZh9fIsD | archivedate=24 June 2014}}{{cite news |url=http://www.affairs.com.pk/News_Operation-Zarb-e-Azb-updates-Evacuation-of-IDPs-from-N-Waziristan-comes-to-an-end_47461 | title=Operation Zarb-e-Azb updates: Evacuation of IDPs from N Waziristan comes to an end | work=affairs.com.pk | date=24 June 2014 | accessdate=25 June 2014| archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QagtOq2n| archivedate=25 June 2014}}}} {{term|24 June 2014}} {{defn|Twenty militants were killed and 12 hideouts destroyed in early-morning air strikes in Khyber Agency. Twenty-seven militants were killed in afternoon jet strikes in Mir Ali and the surrounding area, with 11 hideouts and a large weapons cache destroyed.{{Citation |url=https://www.ispr.gov.pk/front/main.asp?o=t-press_release&date=2014/6/24 | title=Press Releases of 24 June | date=24 June 2014 | publisher=[[Inter-Services Public Relations|ISPR]] | accessdate=24 June 2014 | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QZgn1jM4 | archivedate=24 June 2014}} An afternoon suicide car-bomb attempt was foiled in the Spinwam area of North Waziristan. When an explosive-laden vehicle approached a checkpoint outside a civilian hospital, soldiers fired at the vehicle (which exploded 100 meters from the checkpoint. Two soldiers and one civilian were reportedly killed when the roof of a nearby building collapsed from the explosion.}} {{term|25 June 2014}} {{defn|[[Pakistan Air Force]] (PAF) jets destroyed five hideouts in Mir Ali, killing 13 militants.{{Citation |url=https://www.ispr.gov.pk/front/main.asp?o=t-press_release&date=2014/6/25 | title=Press Releases of 25 June | date=25 June 2014 | publisher=[[Inter-Services Public Relations|ISPR]] | accessdate=25 June 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QfgLeBj3|archivedate=28 June 2014}} Twelve militants surrendered to Pakistani forces.}} {{term|26 June 2014}} {{defn|The evacuation of 450,000 civilians was completed, and the operation's second phase began with a ground offensive by the Pakistani military. Seven militants surrendered at the North Waziristan surrender center, bringing the total to 19.{{cite web|title=ISPR Press Releases of 28 June|url=https://www.ispr.gov.pk/front/main.asp?o=t-press_release&date=2014/6/28|date=28 June 2014|work=ISPR|accessdate=28 June 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QfehRJZV|archivedate=28 June 2014|deadurl=no}}{{cite news |url=http://arynews.tv/en/zarb-e-azb-327-militants-killed-so-far-tells-dg-ispr/ | title=Zarb-e-Azb: 327 militants killed so far, tells DG ISPR | work=ARY News | date=26 June 2014 | accessdate=27 June 2014 | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QeMZXlV9 | archivedate=27 June 2014}}}} {{term|27 June 2014}} {{defn|PAF aircraft destroyed six confirmed hideouts on the outskirts of Mir Ali in an evening raid, killing 11 militants. TTP Miranshah Commander Umer was killed on the outskirts of the town by security forces that night.}} {{term|28 June 2014}} {{defn|Militant groups were targeted during the early morning by integrated Pakistani artillery, tank and heavy-weapons fire outside Miranshah, killing seven. An al-Qaeda commander, revealed by initial interrogation as an explosives, IED and suicide-belt expert, was arrested trying to flee from a surrounded base. Three militants were arrested by security forces while trying to cross the [[Indus River]] near [[Mianwali]]. All river crossings were fortified to seal escape routes.}} {{term|29 June 2014}} {{defn|Sixteen militants were killed when PAF fighter jets targeted their hideouts in Mir Ali, North Waziristan.{{cite news|title=Jets strafe militant hideouts; 16 killed|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/728978/jets-strafe-militant-hideouts-16-killed/|date=30 June 2014|accessdate=30 June 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QhsyF3Tq|archivedate=30 June 2014}}{{cite news|title=Zarb-e-Azb: 16 more terrorists eliminated, 7 hideouts smashed|url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/article-152325-Zarb-e-Azb:-16-more-terrorists-eliminated,-7-hideouts-smashed|date=30 June 2014|accessdate=30 June 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QhtAFTPm|archivedate=30 June 2014}} According to military sources, seven militant hideouts, explosives and ammunition dumps were also destroyed in the airstrikes.}} {{term|30 June 2014}} {{defn|Early-morning ground operations began in and around Miramshah. Search operations were conducted by [[infantry]] and the [[Special Services Group]], killing 15 militants. Troops discovered underground tunnels and IED-preparation factories in the cleared areas, with three soldiers reportedly injured in an exchange of fire. The civilian population had been evacuated.{{cite web|title=ISPR Press releases of 30 June|url=https://www.ispr.gov.pk/front/main.asp?o=t-press_release&date=2014/6/30 |publisher=ISPR|accessdate=30 June 2014 | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QkEz6ntG | archivedate=1 July 2014}} Since the beginning of the operation 376 militants were killed and 19 surrendered, with 61 hideouts destroyed in the operation's first phase. Seventeen soldiers were reportedly killed.}} ====July==== {{term|1 July 2014}} {{defn|According to the ISPR, during ground operations in Miranshah a landmine factory was discovered and 225 cylinders, 700 pipes filled with explosive materials and 150 unfinished [[land mine]]s were recovered.{{cite news|title=Haqqani fighters won't be spared either|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/729926/haqqani-fighters-wont-be-spared-either/|date=2 July 2014|work=Express Tribune|accessdate=2 July 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QlLMh8wr|archivedate=2 July 2014}} Two Pakistani soldiers were killed and a third reportedly injured when militants ambushed a military vehicle in Mir Ali, North Waziristan.{{cite web|title=Pakistan reiterates NWA offensive will hit Haqqani network|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/1116308/militant-ambush-in-nwa-kills-two-security-personnel|publisher=DAWN|accessdate=2 July 2014 | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QlyEFgQu| archivedate=2 July 2014}}{{cite news|title=Militant ambush in NWA kills two security personnel|url=http://thefrontierpost.com/article/181419/Militant-ambush-in-NWA-kills-two-security-personnel/|date=1 July 2014|accessdate=2 July 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QlzJVUrb|archivedate=2 July 2014}}{{cite news|title=Two soldiers killed in NWA ambush|url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/Todays-News-13-31324-Two-soldiers-killed-in-NWA-ambush|date=2 July 2014|work=The News|accessdate=2 July 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QlzIBqpN|archivedate=2 July 2014}}}} {{term|2 July 2014}} {{defn|Ten militants were killed when Pakistani helicopters shelled hideouts in the Khar Warsak region, {{convert|12|km}} north of Miramshah, with three hideouts destroyed in the airstrikes.{{cite news|title=Helicopters destroy 3 militant hideouts near Miramshah, kill 10 terrorists|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/730036/helicopters-destroy-3-militant-hideouts-near-miramshah-kill-10-terrorists/|date=2 July 2014|accessdate=2 July 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qlz1V40N|archivedate=2 July 2014}}}} {{term|3 July 2014}} {{defn|The bodies of seven militants were recovered in the Darpa Khel area of Mir Ali. A security official reportedly said, "Bodies were of suspected militants who were gunned down by security forces in Mir Ali tehsil of the agency", adding that the forces had advanced from Mir Ali and Miramshah Bazaar towards the outskirts of the agency after destroying three hideouts in Mir Ali (one of which held foreign militants).{{cite news|title=Bodies of seven suspected militants recovered in North Waziristan|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/730731/bodies-of-seven-suspected-militants-receovered-in-north-waziristan/|date=3 July 2014|work=The Express Tribune|accessdate=5 July 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QprtXjgO|archivedate=5 July 2014}}}} {{term|4 July 2014}} {{defn|Pakistani soldier Niak Fiaz Mohammad was killed by an IED explosion, during a house-to-house search operation in North Waziristan. Mohammed's funeral was held in Bannu before the soldier's body was transported to his hometown, Mansehra. ISPR [[director-general]] Major General Asim Saleem Bajwa said, "We salute the courage and bravery of Niak Fiaz Shaheed."{{cite news|title= NWA blast leaves soldier dead|url=http://www.nation.com.pk/national/05-Jul-2014/nwa-blast-leaves-soldier-dead|date=5 July 2014|work=The Nation|accessdate=5 July 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QpsefDcj|archivedate=5 July 2014}} A Pakistani soldier from [[Azad Kashmir]] was killed in the Jord region of North Waziristan. The soldier, Sadheer Ismail from Malsi Ghari Dupatta, was buried in his family cemetery. [[Pakistan Army]] personnel attended Ismail's funeral, where friends praised his determination and resolve.{{cite news|title=In the line of duty: AJK soldier laid to rest|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/731792/in-the-line-of-duty-ajk-soldier-laid-to-rest/|date=7 July 2014|work=The Express Tribune|accessdate=8 July 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QurTBsYo|archivedate=8 July 2014}}}} {{term|5 July 2014}} {{defn|Airstrikes targeted Miramshah and the village of Boya, destroying five militant hideouts, caves, and an ammunition cache. The early-morning strikes killed 20 militants, most of whom were reportedly Uzbeks.{{cite web|title=ISPR Press releases of 5 July|url=https://www.ispr.gov.pk/front/main.asp?o=t-press_release&date=2014/7/5 |publisher=ISPR|accessdate=6 July 2014 | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QrPCcwJh | archivedate=6 July 2014}} A Pakistani soldier was killed during the ground offensive that morning when an IED exploded.}} {{term|6 July 2014}} {{defn|Hundreds of Taliban fighters reportedly cut their hair and beards to flee the operation. According to IDPs, the Taliban disguised themselves in the weeks before the Pakistan Army operation. Although the militants advocated ''[[sharia]]'' in Pakistan and were contemptuous of Western culture, refugees said that in North Waziristan the militants enjoyed imported products.{{cite news|title=Taliban cut hair and beards to flee army assault|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/1117448/taliban-cut-hair-and-beards-to-flee-army-assault|accessdate=6 July 2014|work=[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]]|agency=[[Agence France-Presse|AFP]]|date=6 July 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6R2YEGmIB |archivedate=13 July 2014}}{{cite news|title=Taliban cut hair and beards to flee Pakistan Army assault|url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/south-asia/taliban-cut-hair-and-beards-to-flee-pakistan-army-assault_945421.html|date=6 July 2014|work=Zee News|accessdate=6 July 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QrQPRZEf|archivedate=6 July 2014}}}} {{term|7 July 2014}} {{defn|Pakistani Chief of Army Staff General Raheel Sharif visited North Waziristan. Sharif was received by Lieutenant General Khalid Rabbani, the Peshawar corps commander, and briefed by the [[general officer commanding]] for the operation. He commended the troops for their determination, commitment and resolve, praising the progress achieved since the beginning of the operation.{{cite web|title=ISPR Press Releases of 7 July|url=https://www.ispr.gov.pk/front/main.asp?o=t-press_release&date=2014/7/7|date=7 July 2014|work=ISPR|accessdate=7 July 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QtJCGc4k |archivedate=7 July 2014}}}} {{term|8 July 2014}} {{defn|Pakistani Defence Minister Khawaja Asif said in an interview with Radio Pakistan that 400 militants and 20 Pakistani soldiers had been killed so far in the operation. Although he declined to provide a time frame for the operation's end, he expressed a resolve to finish as early as possible.{{cite news|title=Operation Zarb-e-Azb: 400 militants killed so far, says Khawaja Asif|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/732742/operation-zarb-e-azb-400-militants-killed-so-far-says-khawaja-asif/|date=8 July 2014|work=The Express Tribune|accessdate=8 July 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Quq8o56Z|archivedate=8 July 2014}} Airstrikes by the PAF killed 13 militants (including foreigners) in the Digaan area of North Waziristan, according to an ISPR press release. Seven militant hideouts were also destroyed.{{cite news|title=13 more terrorists killed in Operation Zarb-e-Azb|url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/article-153148-13-more-terrorists-killed-in-Operation-Zarb-e-Azb-|date=8 July 2014|work=The News|accessdate=8 July 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Quq8yAIU|archivedate=8 July 2014}}{{cite news|title=Another 13 Militants Killed In North Waziristan, Says ISPR|url=http://newsweekpakistan.com/another-13-militants-killed-in-north-waziristan-says-ispr/|date=8 July 2014|work=Newsweek Pakistan|accessdate=8 July 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Quq8tDaB|archivedate=8 July 2014}}}} {{term|9 July 2014}} {{defn|Pakistani airstrikes targeted three hideouts, killing 11 militants in Shawal.{{cite news|title=Zarb-e-Azb: 80 percent of Miranshah cleared; 11 more killed in jet bombing|url=http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/national/10-Jul-2014/zarb-e-azb-80-percent-of-miranshah-cleared-11-more-killed-in-jet-bombing|date=10 July 2014|work=Daily Times|accessdate=10 July 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qxt4p6fr|archivedate=10 July 2014}} Ground operations continued in Miramshah, which was 80-percent cleared.}} {{term|10 July 2014}} {{defn|The Pakistani army invited local and international media to Miramshah to observe the militant facilities. Flags, weapons and explosive materials were shown. ISPR Director Major General Asim Bajwa and Operation Commander Major General Zafar Khan briefed the media on the operation's progress. They said that as many as 400 terrorists were killed and another 130 injured to date. Eleven IED factories were uncovered, and over 2,000 IEDs confiscated. Bajwa said that underground tunnels built by the militants (one a kilometer long) had also been discovered: "This (Miranshah) was one of their major base, we have dislodged them from here and now they are on the run, We have also discovered their command and control centre, which would definitely affect their capabilities."{{cite news|title=Operation Zarb-e-Azb: Terrorists are on the run, says Bajwa|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/733537/operation-zarb-e-azb-terrorists-are-on-the-run-says-bajwa/|date=10 July 2014|work=The Express Tribune|accessdate=10 July 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qxta7cTc|archivedate=10 July 2014}}}} {{term|11 July 2014}} {{defn|Injured Taliban commander [[Adnan Rashid]], al-Qaeda commander Mufti Zubair Marwat and Marwat's two guards were captured by Pakistani security forces in the Shakai Valley of [[South Waziristan]] when they tried to escape from cordoned-off North Waziristan, and were moved to an undisclosed location by army helicopter. Marwat was reportedly the brother of Mufti Sajjad Marwat, an al-Qaeda spokesman for Afghanistan and Pakistan. Rashid was planning to flee to Afghanistan.{{cite news|title=Key TTP commander Adnan Rashid arrested in S Waziristan: sources|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/1119405/key-ttp-commander-adnan-rashid-arrested-in-s-waziristan-sources|date=16 July 2014|work=[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]]|accessdate=16 July 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6R79KxfGi|archivedate=16 July 2014}} The arrest was confirmed by the TTP.{{cite news|title=TTP confirm arrest of key commander Adnan Rashid|url=http://www.nation.com.pk/national/16-Jul-2014/ttp-confirm-arrest-of-key-commander-adnan-rashid|date=16 July 2014|work=The Nation|accessdate=16 July 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6R79z35cy|archivedate=16 July 2014}}}} {{term|12 July 2014}} {{defn|Thirteen militants, primarily foreign, were killed in an early-morning PAF airstrike after firing rockets at a security checkpoint in Mir Ali; seven hideouts and an ammunition cache were also destroyed.{{Cite web|title=ISPR Press Release of 12 June|url=https://www.ispr.gov.pk/front/main.asp?o=t-press_release&date=2014/7/12|date=12 July 2014|work=ISPR|accessdate=13 July 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6R26sZxBw|archivedate=13 July 2014}}{{cite news|title=13 militants killed in fresh air strikes in Mirali|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/734739/13-militants-killed-in-fresh-air-strikes-in-mirali/|date=12 July 2014|work=The Express Tribune|accessdate=13 July 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6R26sO3KU|archivedate=13 July 2014}} The connection of the cleared area in Miramshah and the Miramshah-Dattakhel road continued. In Khar Warsak and Zartangi, security forces discovered six motorcycle IEDs, two vehicle IEDs, two 12.7 mm guns, one 14.5 mm gun, three vehicles and eleven [[explosive belt]]s during the previous 24 hours. Two explosive-laden vehicles were also destroyed in airstrikes at Degan. Three militants, including one Uzbek, were arrested in Boya. Two suicide bombers were identified and chased, but they blew themselves up when encircled by security forces near the town. Eighteen militants were killed in PAF airstrikes in the Mosaki area, {{convert|25|km}} east of Miramshah, and artillery shelling in the Kharkamar area, {{convert|30|km}} west of Miramshah.
